Um no its not putting up results because no one plays it. No one plays it because its not putting up results. If that sounds circular, welcome to deck development when no one knows what your deck is, how it operates, and most importantly, no one wants to bother to learn.
The idea that chalice, revoker or needle can't be beaten in and of themselves is pretty funny. There are multiple ways around all three of those cards, you need multiple pieces of permenent based disruption, and even then it depends what they are and how much of a clock you are putting on while you do that.
Even then, breakfast can blank your creatures pretty easily if they don't have evasion.
The removal argument is also not as powerful as you think it is. Bolt for example doesn't do anything most of the time. 2 mana removal on the draw can be kind of loose sometimes, Snapcaster into that removal is laughably bad.
At the end of the day, when you try to update a deck with new printings that hasn't even been discussed by the more casual aspects of the community since 2015, these are the kind of comments that happen.
I would suggest you take a look at a more modern list than one from I don't even know when, and did you even look at a list before making sweeping judgements about the viability of it? Like, everything you mentioned is either false or exaggerated.

True. Even so heres a rundown on some gotchas:
-Aluren is a symmetrical effect. You can also cast creatures for free!
-Food chain is a mana ability, you cannot shut it off with needle, though you can name it just fine.
- Once you say "okay" to your opponents vial activation, its too late, the man/woman is in play and taxing you.
- for the love of god, don't use removal on infects guys on their combat if you can help it. If you can, mainphase that stuff or cast it on their end step.
- Standstill retriggers everytime a spell is cast. So yeah be careful.
- Dredge is a replacement effect, its really hard to interact with. I don't think it even uses the stack.
thats all for now, just the stuff i thought of off the top of my head. It would be cool to compile all these nuggets in one place and sort them by category, but thats... a lot of work.

on azami vs hapless resercher: researcher could easily be better, but azami protecting you at the end is more and more of a relevant thing. Does that outweigh azami costing 5 freaking mana? idk. Needs testing.
I made this build to ensure Mentor had support. After this, I'm never playing Mentor over true name again. Was way too unreliable as a kill card. i would play it, it would stick, and it would just beat for 2 a turn, 3 sometimes. I strongly suspect the problem with mentor in this shell is it rewards proactive spell casting, and this list has not nearly enough of that.
On stoneforge: They're going back in and they're staying there unless something weird happens. having a plan b is way too good in way too many situations, and honestly the creatures are very resillient against other creatures. Also you have a ton of incedental guys.
On the amount of mana: This is going to blow your mind, but if it wasnt for color considerations and to a lesser extent the current sideboard plan, I'd look hard at cutting another land. Yeah. I didn't believe it either, I kept telling myself it couldnt be correct, but honestly, With a vial in play your lands are entirely irrelevant outside of casting cantrips and activating stoneforge. Without a vial, you still only have to cast maybe 6 mana worth of spells over the course of an average game, with that number going up the longer your deck feeds you garbage. Your combo only costs you three mana. 3 for recruiter if something goes wrong with a piece, 1 for a cantrip, its not much at all.

Biggest advice I can give is just to take a second to read cards your opponents play if you are at all unfamiliar with what it does.
I see a lot of people that just assume that some card card that their opponent plays doesn't matter and then just die to it.

WRITING.TITLE: Just another breakfast report.
WRITING.TEXT:
round 1 vs burn loss 1-2. game 1 I didn't force vortex because i'm an idiot and it beat me. game 2 He tapped out for double rift bolt on turn 3 and just died to my combo. game 3 We both drew like garbage but i also played like garbage.
round 2 vs UB reanimator win 2-1 (this one went to turns!) Game one: I resolved a Vial through a pregame Chancellor reveal. He cast Careful study into Lotus petal- Reanimate on Chancellor, I had the combo in hand but had to wait a turn. He had Thoughtseize for my other half, so i just Vialed in creatures and started the race. I lost because i let him hit me one too many times with chancellor and forgot he could dome me for 2 with brutality like the idiot i am.
game two: He went dread of night into needle, so i recruited lab man and beat down with blue 1/1s and that guy while holding countermagic+ surgical.
game 3 was weird, involving celephid beatdown from me and a mull into awkward 1 lander from him. I eventually counter all his reanimators on the crucial turn, followed by an attack for lethal. He had entomb on his turn one, but i Surgicaled his grislebrand then therapied his brainstorm leaving him with a bunch of dead stuff.
round 3 vs death/taxes win 2-0 game 1:
my turn 1 :fetch for tundra, vial. his turn 1 : cavern, mom. my turn 2: vial nomad, play cavern on wizard, cast illusionist, kill you.
game 2 was bizarre, I cant give full details. the board state at the end was:
Me: Vial on three, combo in play, recruiter in play, Labman and Disenchant in hand, tundra island untapped, plains tapped.
Him: Thalia in play with a Jitte(2 counters) and a sword of war/peace equipped, three vials and no cards in hand. he also just had a Stoneforge come in off the vial, so he could Jitte equip swing. He was tapped out, but had 4 plains 1 port. Jitte has 2 counters.
It is his end step. How did i win this game? We will come back to that mess.
round 4: vs MUD loss 1-2.
Honestly I was tired here, but here is what i remember:
game one: We had some back and forth, my opponent had a chalice which was invalidated by vial except in two ways that only came up because I drew the one of dread return and the game one configuration of the deck couldn't cast it naturally, which if I'd realized so earlier I could have just spent 2 turns drawing up to 8 cards so I could discard it, as I had dealt with the first bit of pressure. Whatever, happens, play better/ build better.
game 2 I disenchanted his chalice on end step, then cast the other half of my combo and killed him.
game three: I don't remember except that his hate was multiple torpor orb, and a chalice. i was stuck with 1 drops and recruiters in hand, and then he dropped platinum angel and beat me up with it.
overall 2-2 in matches. I accomplished what i wanted, which was to test mentor over true-name in the board and practice playing the combo through hate.
Shout out to the poor guy who came from the next town over to play only to find out from hearing me talk to my first round burn opponent what he thought of the banning that top got banned. If you want to test to see what you want to play, there's cheap beer and cheaper pizza across the street here and I'm buying.
Props to the lgs giving that guy a refund, it was the decent thing to do.
The Breakfast Tax Dodge/ Solution to the above d t match puzzle:
Go to my turn, Disenchant the Jitte on upkeep while paying for Thalia. Combo off, putting library into yard. Vial in lab man, go to draw step, win game.
Getting to this line required some thinking ahead, as I needed to recruit for lab man the turn prior. I don't always play like garbage.
list at http://manadeprived.com/showdown-recap-march-5th-legacy/. - 2 stoneforge, 1 jitte, 1 SOFI, 2 mother of runes, 1 shaman en kor, 1 scrubland. + 3 probe, 3 swords, 1 recruiter, 1 tundra.
The sideboard changes per event. This time: 1 swords, 3 mentor, 1 underground sea, 2 unearth, 2 disenchant, 1 daze, don't remember the rest(probably wasn't good)

Okay, it seems like most people don't understand how much the mana matters here, so here goes.
First, leyline of the void is highly unlikely to be cast, so take the suggestion to play it with a grain of salt.
Compounding this, this deck cannot support both leyline and force, you then start to cave to hard countermagic. A single force of will backed by a clock will kill you.
On top of this, you cannot play dead cards in a deck that has 28 mana sources and low impact stuff like sword of the meek. Get liquidmetal coating out of there.
As a result of coating being gone, dack fayden is now the worst card in the deck, so cut that entirely.
Add more daretti, that card is the best in the deck not close.
If you want to know what 75 I'm playing this weekend, ill send you a list.
The thing you have to remember about grixis Tezz deck construction is that half your deck doesn't do anything most times, so each card has to be worth a LOT. Otherwise your control and midrange opponents will just counter your first key spell and you cave.

WRITING.TITLE: I don't think I have time to get good at this.
WRITING.TEXT:
I tried guys, I really did. After playing a bunch of fighters that did not appeal to me at all, I discovered Blazbue when Calamity trigger came out. I followed along with the story, picking up each game for that. I picked up a ps2 copy of Guilty Gear: Accent core r at the same time as Continuum shift, and then tried going into the mechanics of the game when I stopped being able to beat the comp in story mode. I got most of my friends up from "button masher" to the point where they can Dragon punch, hodoken, and dash when they wanted to most of the time, even the ones who didn't play video games that often. For the ones who did, I ran them through all the basic systems involved. None of us could remember all the things all the time, but we all knew a couple of ways to at least try to get out of bad situations.
Here's the thing though: the ability to think fast enough to solve problems presented at this speed is either the sole province of supermen or the result of way more practice than I can responsibly put in, and I am pretty certain the former is a myth.
So I am out, maybe I'll try again later, but demands on my time are getting heavier as of late. I could be convinced to get back on the horse if 2 hours of practice a week is going to cut it, but I strongly suspect it is not.
If anyone having trouble with basic execution has questions though, I did teach a bunch of complete casuals how to stop a lazy approach with Sol badguys sick "fire wall shoryouken " variant, so yeah.
Btw, taking someone from " I only play clash of clans, and sometimes Civ5" to "I just spent my previous evening curb-stomping my boyfriend with Noel vermillion" in less than 8 hours over 3 weeks is immensely satisfying.

Okay, I think I see what you're attempting to say here.
I think my the issue I took with what you were saying stems from the fact that I thought you were making a blanket statement instead of talking about cards that are already powerful.
Even in that context, what you actually said the first time is still pretty wonky. It actually directly contradicts this A card or strategy can break a format, if it's both broken and difficult to answer
the qualities are different, but one is a modifier on the other.
from my understanding you said this The fact that an opponent can or can't interact with a card does not determine brokenness. A card or strategy can break a format, if it's both broken and difficult to answer; but those are two different qualities.
and meant this: The fact that an opponent can or can't interact with a card does not determine brokenness in and of itself. A card or strategy can break a format, if it's both broken and difficult to answer; but those are two different qualities.
Saying interaction doesn't matter, than proceeding to list all the ways to interact with will to prove a point is a little weird.
I would say that once a minimum amount of power is reached, the inability to interact with an effect is an indicator of and modifier on power level regardless of even the competitive game in question.

WRITING.TITLE: A big hole in my game [discussion]
WRITING.TEXT:
disclaimer: I typically play legacy and draft.
Hi! I've noticed a petty big hole in my ability to play certain decks/ analyse certain gamestates, which is my inabilty to notice when to switch gameplans when the clues are subtle, and this comes up most often when I am playing a mirror match.
I've noticed it happen at two points: when sideboarding, and when both players have similar board states, and it gets so much worse the more information is hidden.
The good news is, when you choose wrong in legacy, you get punished immediately, so I get good feedback that way. I get to point to exactly what I did wrong and say " that was where I missassigned my role."
heres an example of a board state that usually gets me killed:
My board: 2 x plains, rishadan port, aether vial@3, flickerwisp, thalia guardian of thraben, In hand swords to plowshares.
Oppenent has: 2x plains, port, vial @3, serra avenger, sanctum prelate @1, One unknown card.
The play for me is clearly nothing, but what is my plan here?
example sideboarding disaster in the making: Lands mirror. what is the plan? not individual sideboard cards, but what the heck am I trying to accomplish here? Is it a race or are we trying to go over each other? Am i trying to disrupt or to prevent disruption? note those questions are interlinked.
I'm not trying to get answers on a case by case basis, but to illustrate my core problem of missassigning my role when my role is some combination of fluid and hand dependent, and my opponent has a similar deck/ board state.
until I get this figured out, I can't competently pilot any deck capable of switching gameplans that consists of cards which do similar things like delver variants, lands, or miracles, and even death and taxes to a lesser degree. I actually need to pilot decks with a more shoeboxed plan, which actually keeps me out of most of the tier one strategies of the format.
Hilariously, I'm priced out of brainstorm on the strategic level. I can only cast it even close to correctly in storm or other combo, where the plan is pretty clear. otherwise, i'll missassign my role and promptly lose.
What do you guys suggest I do to learn this aspect of the game? Is there a specific format that showcases the consequnces of the lack of this skill, where I can practice?

WRITING.TITLE: On getting invaded while just trying to play
WRITING.TEXT:
I was going through the depths for the first time and just got the sewer key then I opened the door to the bonfire and got invaded while pressing the button to interact with it, then died in front of the door.
Then the same guy invaded me again, I fought him just before the basilisks in the basement. luckily, he had to kill the things to get to me, and more luckily I beat him. But I never got to even see the petrification breath, and next time through was caught completely by suprise.
Then he invaded me again, and I killed him in a spell and a combo. He didn't come back.
Just to be clear, this wasnt one of the preset invasion guys, he had a name like "ArmRAmor113" or something equally silly, this was a real guy.
This made me curious about pvp etiquite, so i looked it up.
The thing is I don't even care about this facet of online play, and killing a guy in front of his bonfire seems like a dick move.
IDK, just salty i guess.

Imagine you want to cast a spell, so you press the button to do so. after a delay of about a little less than a second*, your spellcaster begins her startup animation. Now stuck like that, you need to "queue up" the direction in which you wish to dodge or walk or whatever, anticipating what the enemy is going to do next.
Under these conditions, It feels like precision is impossible and skill of excecution is irrelevant. I have to play this like a turn based game almost, planning out the next few inputs in advance. I start to beat bosses only when Ive gotten good enough at a certain part of their pattern to be able to take that time to plan instead of react or dodge or whatever.
Not to say this isn't extremely fun in its own way , I'm just hoping that it's sustainable.
I've had to put some into strength to ensure I can even keep up. Magic is really really hit or miss.
might be less than that, I just know I can say "Dracozombie" before my character reacts to a button press, so some predictive reasoning is pretty neccesary.

Every time i go to say something about this deck being terrible, I take another pass over it and realize that yes, there is synergy there, and yes, you did think about this. So 2 constructive pieces of criticism:
First don't just think of walkers as walkers, but things that hit the board and accrue card advantage over time, while also being a win condition. keranos, trading post, and thopter spy network all qualify, but I'm absolutely positive i'm not thinking of some.
Second, If you can make space for chalice in the main, do so. Theres no downside except lack of space, and doing so overloads your opponents removal/ blanks it. You might not need the full four with trinisphere there though.

That line doesnt. I was saying that you dont get to take that line if you had to either GSZ for Vet, or If you only had one GB source in your opener due to the other being plains or volraths stronghold or karakas or something.
You opponent not getting priority is the whole reason I could say what I said.
They also needed to fix it for throwback standard.

You need to therapy turn one if you plan on using veteran explorer on turn 2 though, because you need to play around STP.
To actually answer the question asked, the answer to this question really depends on the rest of your hand. If your hand is disruptive, brainstorm is fine. If you are low on threats that don't immediately generate value, you need to name a removal spell. If your threats generate value, Force of will.
Therapy on turn one is the line you take when you have a 1-2 land hand, and one of those lands is plains or colourless. This kind of crap happens a fair bit, it turns out when you play so many basics your mana can dump on you.
I was 80 percent or something on therapy hits, but that was early 2016 in paper magic. I'm both rusty and too unfamiliar with current lists to get that kind of rate today. Still, this advice should be sound.

So you do not acknowledge that nongames exist?
I'm trying to form a baseline for conversation here. losing sucks, but as I said in the OP, is not my main concern. My main concern is the ability to play the game of magic that I sat down to play.
If my opponent shuts that down, they did their job. If my deck fails to put up token resistance or a token offence, that's a problem.
There is no fun game in which you have no meaningful input. Thats not just magic, that's games in general. The games where that happens and you win are only mitigated by the fact that there is some sort of prize on the line, and then not much. the games where that happens and you lose have no redeeming value most of the time, with the exception being the opponents being pretty nice about it.
The line of thought I have, emotionally, for these games is " I did not sit down for a bad interactive movie, I sat down for magic."
Intellectually, I know that these games happen so infrequently as to be statistically insignificant, maybe %5 -6 percent of games, but i have a hard time separating the emotion from the variance without just moving on to the next game of magic.
This thread is really just a purge of the remaining 5-6 percent of salt games.
Hmm maybe I give the human race too much credit then.

okay let me be even more clear:
losing to wasteland: fine, I should have played more basics. losing to blood moon on turn one: also fine, same reason. losing to counterbalance lock, or lucky topdecks, or my own mistakes, or a deck reg error, or drawing an extra card by accident at comp rel? All totally fine.
The subset of games that I play where neither player has any meaningful impact on the outcome? Yeah this is where the salt comes from.
It also doesn't last longer than it takes for the next "good game of magic," and the more magic I get to play, the less likely this is to happen. For example, a gp? Never salty. A monthly event? Only if there isn't a draft i can get into. Draft till you drop round one loss to screw? Not happening. Prerelease? kick my arse and give me another please.
The commanality is the ability to say "Whatever, I'll just go play magic over there.

again sorry I wasn't more clear in the op.
My salt comes from the specific subsection of games in which neither player has any meaningful influence on the outcome, the ones where it doesn't matter what my oppenent killed me with, I could not play magic.
No amount of money fixes this problem.
If my opponent storms me out of the game, I should have played more turn 0 interaction. That's on me.
If my opponent locks me out with counter top, I should have played more varied mana costs.
If my opponent wastes all my land, I should have played more basics.
If i draw an extra card at comp rel, I needed to be more careful.
However if i mulligan to 5 on the play and see no lands, and then my opponent wins, then neither i nor my opponent had a meaningful impact on the game, with the small exception of him playing a 2/2.
These are not "real games," these are "nongames," and it seems from talking to other people locally that I have a much stricter view that they of what consistutes such.

Interestingly, opening a crummy sealed pool is still a situation that someone can meaningfully influence. Winning with garbage is worth a modicum of bragging rights, if nothing else.
Getting mana screwed can be a problem in deck construction or mulligan decisions, and usually I think about that before I move to the salt step.

should have been more clear.
Its not necessarily the outcome of the game, but how much control I/my opponent has over it. If I lose because I threw away my guy for no value, or my opponent countered all my spells, or even because I screwed up and drew an extra card at comp rel, That's fine. None of those things are affected by the kind of variance that grinds my gears.
mulling twice into a four land hand and drawing two more lands over 4 turns is where I start getting a little bit irate, but only if I run down the list of " Did i build my deck wrong?" type of things, and only until the next game that I have input into.
The salt can only exist inside and immediately after a bad game of magic, one where the outcome of the game is entirely decided by the vagaries of randomness.

I really admire people that can do that, but I don't seem to have it in me. The best approximation I have is to try to recognize when I can positively influence a situation, but of course this appproach can suck in the face of situations beyond my control.
It's interesting because IRL I don't stress over that kind of thing. I suspect that it's because magic obfuscates what you can or can't influence so often that it becomes hard to identify what you have influence over.
Learning a lot about myself here!

I should have been much more clear. I get salty sometimes when I lose matches in which I have such minimal input that what my opponent does to beat me almost doesn't matter. The litmus test for those is " If all my opponents cards were grizzly bears, would they have still won the game?" There is very little to learn from games like that.
I'm approaching all my games like playtesting sessions. In that context, losing "grizzily bear games" are the worst, followed by winning such games, followed by getting the bye, followed by whatever.
The best losses are to grindy control decks, because there is so much data to work with there, followed closely by losing to something I haven't seen before, followed by something I haven't yet played against.

Yeah there is no way I have the extra headspace required to think about how many wins I have in the tournament during a game.
between games however, yeah. I usually reserve my bullcrap for after the match, and then only air it if I can't come up with a reason I deserved to lose to my deck falling apart.
deck constuction, deck choice and mulligan decisions are all places where if I get mana screwed it could be my fault, and I try to consider all of that before I begin the saline infusion.

It's actually pretty hard for me to remember my previous mull to oblivion while I'm playing a game of magic, mostly because I'm trying to win my current game of magic.
If I'm playing a nongame though, whether I'm winning it or losing it, remembering the previous nongame becomes really easy.

Intellectually, this is actually really easy. as I said though, it's really hard to divorce the emotion from the variance when the sample size is always small.
As always though, the current cure for me is more magic.

The weird thing is though, I'm continually told that I assume I have control over more than I do.
I think I'm starting to realize that I'm actually suffering from an entitlement to the ability to play a "good" game of magic, one where each player is able to attempt to excecute their gameplans unless halted by the gameplan of the opponent.

I normally play legacy, but when I can't deal with the "low" side of the random I switch formats to reorient my perspective.
Like, as bad as cantriping into garbage is, at least cantrips exist in legacy. Drawing 4 straight lands in draft sucks.

Yeah the salt only lasts until the next good game of magic, and doesn't usually happen within a game I still have a chance of winning.
The guy I don't wanna turn into is Frank Lepore who is so salty at so much that I don't want to ever watch another video with him in it.

WRITING.TITLE: On dealing with Tilt.
WRITING.TEXT:
Lately I realize that I'm getting a little too salty when I lose. I recognize that variance is a thing in magic, and i feel like the reason why take things so hard is because I just don't get to play enough magic. 4-7 matches per week is just not enough to divorce the salt from the variance.
I should add that the way I "desalinate" is always by playing more magic. My goal in any given tournament is to play the maximum amount of magic, sometimes to the detriment of my win loss record but not to the detriment of my opponents.
I should also add that traveling an 1 - 1.5 hours to play 3-4 rounds of magic and then spending that same time traveling back makes getting the bye seem awful in the context of my goal of playing the most possible magic.

WRITING.TITLE: Bad programming resources and how to identify when you're looking at them
WRITING.TEXT:
I've been having a hard time understanding the basics of various things for a while now, and it may be because of the tools i'm using to learn. I'm getting there, but it is extremely slow going.
I just last week noticed that the vast majority of learning resources I had been using are marked as discouraged resources here.
I usually see a cool new concept, make sure i understand it, then go to implement it and realize i don't understand it at all. This usually results in me spending 20+ hours over the next week or so trying to figure out what it is about the latest thing that i don't understand.
My understanding of a thing is entirely based on if i got exactly that thing working before, because i have no confidence that i can get a variant of that thing running in any reasonable amount of time.
Not having milestones on a reasonable path to proficiency is also eroding any confidence I may have left. Even a " Now that you know X, Y and Z, you should be able to do this" would be helpful.
I have no idea where my gaps even are, and this might be due to the moving from tool to tool and resource to resource I've done every few months.
I would just like to have something like a way to compare what I think i know, what i can actually execute, and what I should know after 4 years at this.

This is one of the most inconsistent things I've ever seen. not even a green brainstorm can fix it.
For reference: Ant is a combo deck that looks to win on turn 2-3. it usually plays 14 lands. Those lands all produce colored mana. Ant also has 4 other free sources of mana. Ant also has 4 brainstorm, 4 ponder, 4 probe and a Sensei's divining top or preordain in order to filter through its draws.
This thing has nothing resembling any of that, and has less land, some of which cant cast spells on its own. This is a disaster waiting to happen.
So in the interest of constructive criticism, here is how i would build what it seems like you want to do here.
dorks 4 birds 4 hierach
locks: 4 thalia heretic cathar 4 winter orb 4 root maze
interaction: 4 swords to plowshares
green suns package: 1 dryad militant 1 dryad arbor 4 green suns zenith 2 scryb ranger 1 quasali pridemage
beaters: 4 greenbelt rampager/greenwheel liberator / dependent on windswept heath 2 thrun the last troll 3 knight of the reliquary/ dependent on heath
mana: 4 windswept heath 4 wasteland 9 forest 1 plains
the rest are up to you, but honestly this whole idea seems like a worse version of sylvan plug. I'd consider that unless you are under REALLY tight budgetary constraints. The deck i listed has it's own set of problems.
cards to consider: renegade ralier tarmogoyf / I assumed budgetary concerns

WRITING.TITLE: Are mtgo results valid at all for anything but figuring out the mtgo meta?
WRITING.TEXT:
I just looked and Death and taxes has only 5-0 d 4 times out of 96 undefeateds, which gives it around the same win rate as dredge.
We know that's not right, but the source has it as a deck to beat and has done so for a while.
I know why theres no taxes, thats not the issue.
I don't think we can use Mtgo results when prepping for paper tournaments.
Come to think of it, I don't think wizards should use mtgo results when considering bannings, and I think people should consider paper legacy and online legacy two different formats when discussing the health of the meta.
I'm willing to be proven wrong, this is more off the cuff than anything.
Your best green 2 drop is visionary.

probably can't beat any reasonable taxes curve, but my point was that D T looks to be a much less prevalent archetype online.
A cursory glance at mtgo 5-0 lists shows only 4 taxes lists in the last 14 days.
thats 4/96, not counting the legacy challenge.
dredge has 3/96, which means "dodge D T" is about as valid a plan as "dodge dredge."

burn is also an absolutely fantastic way to get a hands on feel for the more subtle ways in which the power level of legacy differs from modern. as well as learn which play patterns are open for punishment and how.
You'll learn that cracking a fetch at the wrong time can be exploited by burning to play around counterspells, and that price of progress is possibly the most terrifying burn spell ever printed.
If you stick with burn, you'll learn that the deck has a suprising amont of flex in how it attacks a meta.

Look at the "decks to beat" on the source. Its easy to see metas where eldrazi and BR reanimator get wrecked. Or elves, or lands, or sneak show, or storm, or a half dozen other things I'm not thinking of.
These metas are common. Hell we lived in all of them at various points throughout 2016- 2017.

Burn WILL pants people unfamiliar with the format. The first time they tap out thinking that they are safe because you only have 2 cards in hand, then you bolt, price of progress fireblast them out of the game, "Just the Burn deck" wont be a thing they will say for a while.
That goes for you too. 4 damage for free and 6-8 with 2 mana completely changes how many cards they need in hand to kill you. 1 mana, 1 card three damage is modern burn, modern fire philosophy. in legacy its more like 1.5 mana ,1 card, 4 damage. This makes it so that burn needs 5 cards or less to kill you rather than 7.

WRITING.TITLE: Tezz mini tournament report, ramblings on local meta
WRITING.TEXT:
Ended up not going to the Saturday one and 3-1 ing with tezzerator on Friday. Found 1 transmute under my couch last minute.
Lost to miracles 1-2, beat dredge 2-0, UB reanimator 2-1, and GU eldrazi stompy 2-0.
Stompy featured maindeck trinisphere and elder deep fiend.
meta was very different from previous three weeks, multiple copies of UB reanimator, BR,reanimator, burn, dredge, and deadguy, with much less miracles, stompy, death and taxes, and other chalice decks than usual. filling out the meta with jund, lands,aggro loam, and 1 delver deck.
The Breakfast deck is kinda bad against bug decks with push because of the sheer volume of interaction those decks have. Push + Decay + Thoughtseize + Deathrite + Force to start with, Golgari Charm + Surgical in the board. I could beat some of this pre-push because Decay+ Deathrite + Force is too slow sometimes and not enough some of the other times, but push gives that deck 1 mana creature removal pre-board.
post- board transform is terrible in the face of golgari charm and increased -1-1 effects, to fight True-name out of bug.
It doesn't look like people have adapted to new printings yet though, Hmm.

as in, right now, you have decks that are non-blue that pick up games against other non-blue decks, but only exist really to target the blue decks of the format. This means that the biggest threat to some of these decks is each other. (and consistency obv.)
So as i understand it, You want to get these things out of the format entirely so that people will only play good decks(blue decks).
You acknowledge at the start of the article that people cannot switch decks that they are invested in, so you acknowledge that the people affected by these changes will not be able to find even the success that they have, so they will have to either change decks or quit the format.
I guess I just dont know what you are trying to accomplish.

You're right. That isn't how winning a war or RTS works. From the videos I've seen, that's how winning the campaign of this rts in particular works, and I cant say anything different for multiplayer because they haven't shown us any yet.
Let me be clear: When i say you can throw away units, I mean that from what I've seen, in the campaign, throwing away units is something that you can do on the regular and not get punished enough to create any real additional challenge in finishing the level.
And yes textures are lazy. not bad in and of themselves, but in the context of the other textures surrounding them. Not lazy enough that they can be ignored completely to allow a focus on gameplay (dawn of war 1, starcraft 2, meridian new world) and not detailed enough that they draw your attention(Dawn of war 2, company of heroes, Grey goo) But some in-between state, of thinking hard about what game they wanted to make, but not thinking about the design aspects affected by the changes made to make that game.
So, half-assed basically(Although i realize the danger in minimizing the amount of thought that did go into this, and that they probably think they DID think this through all the way.
I also realize that Multiplayer could operate differently, emphasizing unit preservation because of the increased need and difficulty of holding an extremely important objective.
I still cant buy it on account of not being able to distinguish a damn thing. These aren't my main complaints, and i really hope that more people don't take them as such.
My main problem is that between overdone particles, extra-bland textures, things like rangers looking like guardians, lockstep model animations, Size-of-Model being uniformly the same, health bars blocking the unit behind them, and so forth. the game is unwatchable for me and by extension unplayable for me.

Yeah i know what they said, but they would have to decide to redefine what they want by clarity pretty freaking soon and now that the game is A: well received by their target audience(Not people who like the type of rts that relic popularized)
and B: fairly close to release
I believe it will be up to a mod community to 'create' and popularize the game that they actually wanted.

WRITING.TITLE: Dawn of war 3: I legitamately can't tell what is happening onscreen.
WRITING.TEXT:
I played dawn of war 1 and 2, and if the footage is anything to go by this game is basically unplayable for me.
I can't see any unit that any eldar unit is shooting at.
I can't see any unit behind the giant heatlh bars.
There are no unit type indicators, which wouldn't be a problem if it wasn't for all this bloom.
Everyone moves in lockstep, how hard would it be to just make stagger the animations a little. Just assign a number to each unit, and put a bit of a delay on all the ones with an odd number. Actually, get me to do it, I'll code it for you, I volunteer. I did just do exactly this five hours ago.
I have a buddy who is a professional artist who told me that this game breaks a lot of rules of character design 101, the main thing being that a characters silhouette should have a shape distinct from the others.
He also said the textures are generally lazy. I replied that my eyes wanted to slide off the backgrounds, but defended it by saying that they wanted it to run on low end computers. Then i saw the frame rate drop and facepalmed.
One of the things i really like about the 40k universe is that it doesn't matter what aspect of the IP you happen to be playing, things operate the same way. A shuriken cannon is the same whether you're playing Dawn of war or Battlefleet gothic.
What the heck is going on in the eldar trailer? I think the dire avengers have shuriken cannons and the rangers have brightlances? (first 15 minutes of the trailer, after that my head started to hurt.)
This is particularly bonkers because they said they did all this stuff for clarity. Pretty clear this game is unplayable for me without a change in character design, animation design, and a generous brown layer(Which definitely is not the way you want to fix this, by making everything more brown. Also not likely to happen, first they have to acknowledge that this is a problem.)
sucks, i was looking forward to this until i saw pics, then cautiously optimistic until i saw video, then hoping all races weren't a trianwreck until i saw eldar, now i might forget 2 years from now how bad this was and buy on a steam sale for 10 dollars.
My only hope is that a mod community fixes this. if the tools aren't garbage, I might try my hand. Depends how much control we have, but custom animations and assets are things we have had access to before in this series, withe the exception of the GFWL fiasco.
Bonus: No exp? looks like we throw our marines and eldar into a meat grinder. I understand big battles, but there's little reason to micro if you can throw units away like this.
Why are marines, eldar and orks the same size?
Those buildings look a little bland. Sure that objective looks like a com tower, but from a high end mobile game or something.
Is it just me or does Starcraft look more GrimDark than this? I mean, graphics are less important than gameplay, but when you have things this bright you undercut the setting, which undercuts the story, which undercuts the emotionanal investment in the campaign, which ... undercuts gameplay. Huh. Well Then.

WRITING.TITLE: Celaphid breakfast 2016: Revenge of the Squid Wizard Army: Fnm Report!
WRITING.TEXT:
first up the list: combo 9 celaphid illusionist 4 nomads en-kor 4 shaman en-kor 1
kill 7 narcomoeba 3 angel of glory's rise 1 azami, lady of scrolls 1 labrotory maniac 1 dread return 1
protection 16 force of will 4 daze 3 cabal therapy 3 aether vial 4 mother of runes 2
search 3 recruiter of the guard 3
cantrips 7 brainstorm 4 ponder 3
lands 18 cavern of souls 1 hallowed fountain 2 underground sea 2 flooded strand 4 polluted delta 4 island 1 starlit sanctum 1 plains 1 scrubland 1 karakas 1
sideboard: 3 true-name, 2 phantasmal image,3 StP, 2 dark confidant,2 disenchant, 1 grand abolisher, 1 therapy, 1 Winter orb.
The combo is to assemble celephid illusionist plus an en-kor,mill your deck getting your narcos, then dread return angel of glory's rise and tap your lab man to azami FTW.
This list is super raw, the numbers are all wrong, and the santcum shouldn't be there.
Round 1: infect Game 1 My opponent mulls to five and cant find pump, disruption, or cantrips. I kill him turn 5 after brainstorm, ponder, ponder fetching away garbage the whole time, i finally recruit for nomad. I board out teh combo Game 2 i therapy and miss, my opponent has surgical for therapy and i don't force, so he gets the one in my hand and sees how i boarded. i swords his inkmoth on turn 3 and my opponent draws like garbage. he trys to kill me with noble hierarch, but swords daze force blue card are having none of that. my board when the game ends is double true name vial, some lands.
round 2 burn Game 1 opponent mulls to five, i kill turn three.
keep the combo in the deck, board daze for therapy Game 2 I draw 1 land all game, fortunately daze and force hold down the fort while i get vials to 2 and 3, killing my opponent on turn 5. my opponent drew like garbage, five lands is not where you want to be in burn.
round 3 D T Game 1 he doesn't leave up any interaction against my fetch island vial start, then dies to cavern into squid wizard, vial in nomad, kill you. He had StP in hand.
Game 2 Board out the combo,force of will, 2 daze. Board in all fifteen cards.
This one is a bit of a grind, but my answers matched up and I ended the game with true name copied by phantasmal image and nomads en-kor to infinity block.
Round 4 White Eldrazi Game 1 He plays Warping Wail on my nomad then follows up with big Thalia. then he procees to brick so i can play karakas and my combo. dead turn 5.
Board: Get that combo out of there Game 2 He plays thalia and rest in peace that i dont care about, wastes me a little, resolves chalice at one, then draws land for three turns. Meanwhile my board becomes true-name true- name, image copy true name, recruiter, image copy recuiter, shaman en kor. My hand is force, disenchant, redundant true-name, dark confidant, brainstorm, Vial.
He tells me he has no good answer to true name except for racing it, which was harder now that his deck had all that hate in it now.
4-0 in matches, 8-0 in games good enough for Jace Tms.
overall this actually wasn't good for the testing puposes I wanted, too many people drew bad. I cant really draw that many conclusions. Whatever.
Sure was fun though!

Yeah people really just don't look at other decks when approching the format. You're not wrong, its just your conclusion is misleading.
Conversion rate is what is important here, but we cant have that data for the vast majority of tournaments.
If deck A has 5 players, and deck B has 10 players, and they both put 1 person in top 8, guess which deck was better for that tournament?
This is what happened with BR reanimator. No one took it seriously until they saw it present a high conversion rate at eternal weekend, but the deck had no new printings and existed forever before that. Everything in there had been done before, even in concert with each other, but that was the first time it had been played at an event where people could say: This deck has a high conversion rate.

No.
$t4ks (not stax) is a deck that originated in vintage as a way to solve the base blue infested meta. it has smokestack in it, but the deck was called The four thousand dollar solution.
interpose the s and the t and that gives you Stacks.
later the deck focussed more on the cards smokestack and the name changed a bit.
nowadays vintage largely has no "stax and it has been replaced with workshop aggro."
I looked at that pile of edh cards, and, while it is a prison strategy, you dont get to call it stax if you don't have smokestack the card as a central part of your gameplan.
This is what happens when you culturally appropriate part of the history of another groups format. Fogeys like me get excited that you're talking about magic history and click, and then channel the ensuing disappointment into educating you on the difference between their old thing and your new thing.

WRITING.TITLE: An Interesting Format Observation
WRITING.TEXT:
i just noticed how many widely played decks have key cards that happen to be trinket mage targets.
miracles - top eldrazi- chalice storm- lions eye diamond death and taxes - aether vial lands- mox diamond
Its almost like if you arent playing delver or midrange, you need to ask yourself why you aren't playing a trinket.
Obviously with legacy being as diverse as it is there are some exceptions, like show and tell and reanimator, probably elves too.
I don't know if this is useful as anything other than food for thought, but it sure as heck makes why chalice is insane in this meta crystal clear if for some dumb reason it wasn't already.
Wow, I've never seen so many people misunderstand in my life.(hyperbole). my point wasn't "everyone, lets play trinket mage" that card is terrible in the majority of decks that have blue mana. my point was "In addition to all the cards people put in their decks for consistency and efficiency reasons, look at all these engine and glue pieces that also get hit by chalice at zero and one. Also tier 2+ strategies tend not to have one."
Just for future reference, how many people here know of the reference to 0-1 casting cost artifacts as trinkets? it might help me write something like this so that i don't get chewed out because people focus on something i didn't actually type.
m14 rules update july 13 2013. its not recent, but words of wind cant give you infinite land drops anymore.

WRITING.TEXT:
decklist ( completly misbuilt due to card availibility) 4 ancient tomb 4 polluted delta 2 flooded strand 2 volcanic island 2 underground sea 2 island 1 swamp 3 wasteland 1 urborg, tomb of yawgmoth 1 inventors fair 1 darkslick shores 1 academy ruins 4 mox diamond 2 dimir signet 4 tezzeret, agent of bolas 3 dack fayden 3 daretti, genius iconiclast 4 baleful strix 3 thopter foundry 3 sword of the meek 2 toxic deluge 1 ensaring bridge 1 phyrexian revoker 4 chalice of the void 1 sudden shock ! 1 transmute artifact

woke up on sunday, wanted to play anything but d t, only had grixis tezz as an alternative.
leave at 9:50 to arrive for a 12:00 event. easy game right?
10:00 - go to pay for lemonade at shoppers, cashier #1 has line 8 deep, cashier#2 is in the back doing something for the 1 customer in front of me for 8 minutes. he comes back and the other line has served three people, i walk out to see my bus drive away. Hmm.
11:30 - Miss my stop. This ones on me.HMM.
11:42 - arrive.
eta: 1 hour 20 minutes at the outside. real time: 1 hour 52 min. HMM HMM . eta needs revision. tournament starts at 12:30 instead of 12:00 cause a judge had to be shipped in. (cue mental image of judge arriving via battletech-style dropship)
39 oldwalkers, none of this gatewatch bullcrap 6 rds top 8 (lllemonadeeee)
don't have real notes, writing from memory, already wrecked from lack of food. LEMONAD-
round 1 STORM - ANT -Togores list - player experience level : competent beginner, Storm on play.
my opponent fetches for sea and plays ponder, i waste his sea, he fetches island and plays top. i cast chalice on 1 and my opponent passes. i play sword of the meek, my opponent tops on his end step. then he goes so deep into the tank i think hes gonna drown.
stage 1 of top thinking: cool, maybe he overthinks it. stage 2 of top thinking: cmon man we got two more games to play!
at this point i have no idea what hes on. hes played misty, misty as fetches, usea island as land, top ponder as spells. first i thought it was bug delver, otherwise he would've got island, right? nope. top. shardless dosen't play top so i put him on- get this - bug standstill. then he tanked for over five minutes.
stage three of top thinking: wow okay no ones this bad at resolving top, somethings up. Hes trying to figure out if he can kill me. NO ONE takes this long.
stage four: i begin piecing together what his hand is based on what i have in play, what he does, and what his presideboard configuration must be. Turns out I'm only off by two cards.
stage five, acceptance: he stops thinking, untaps and draws, plays out LED, petal,petal. volc and passes the turn. i proceed to dack his petal and transmute for lil rex revoker on LED. He mini combos, but then dosent have the red mana to PIF due to the lock on LED. He dies just after that, tezz ult then 5/5 put it away.
I'm just glad i had plays during my opponents top activation.
game 2 opponent kills me through chalice. at this point i start to wonder if my opponent isnt playing 4 dark ritual or something. ability to play around chalice is disturbing...
game 3 the game progresses to the point where i have double chalice on one. my opponent has echoing truth, I have force of will, tezz puts it away with 5/5 chalices.
2-1 games 1-0 matches. cool goblin piker bro.
round 2: eldrazi stompy- player experience level: competent beginner, i'm on play.
game 1 : I play land go. he goes mana source into mimic, i waste him. he attacks plays mana source into mimic and i waste him again. he plays mana source attack pass, i play mox diamond pitch tomb fetch land and deluge x-1, and he blanks on mana for way too long.
game 2: he surgicals all my fetchlands, needles naming wasteland, then i set up bridge and proceed to assemble thopter sword at my leisure. I really hope hes not still kicking himself.
4-1 games 2-0 matches. elvish ranger. sweet!
Round three: Infect - player experience level: seasoned vet, hes playing first.
he starts pendelhaven into hierach, i play waste and pass, he plays inkmoth nexus and passes back. i think a moment, go to waste his nexus, he activates and uses vines. hmm. i play waste and waste nexus on his upkeep. it works, he plays foothills. Then this beating occurs: "play ancient tomb, chalice 1?" float blue, brainstorm, daze chalice, fetch. untap, land pass. "play land chalice 1?" spell pierce your chalice. Well crap then, pass turn. untap, brainstorm blighted agent. okay still got outs. untap, "play strix?" force of will . okay, "bridge"? "cards in hand?" Uh oh. "One." untap draw land, attack with agent, invigorate into berserk. :0
game 2 waste a wasteland on irrelavent dual, lose to inkmoth.
" There is no game you deserve to win, but plenty you deserve to lose."
4-3 in games , 2-1 in matches Dreg reaver! take me back to the forest! DRINK MOAR LEMO
round 4 Bant with tamyo field researcher - player experince level: sesoned vet.

revoker and port against miracles, wasteland and combat creatures against delver. active jitte is a lock piece.
crusader over big thalia is probably a mistake depending on your meta, eldrazi is extremely difficult to beat without that card, now the deck is durduling with recruiter and prelate.
understand that with the new options, your cmc is higher and now you are worse against non-blue, which matters depending on the meta you are expecting to face. remember that there are no sacred cows, if you get wrecked by miracles and delver, play more disruptive creatures. if jund and eldrazi dump in your cereal, play more flyers, thalias and lieges in your 75. sometimes mangara is too slow. sometimes theres so much eldrazi, 4th mom makes no sense.
Sometimes you get a meta where no one respects wasteland and you get to play 4 arbiter 4 ghost quarter 4 path. -1 stoneforge.
Prison is a form of control. Bring the right answers to your opponents threats.

WRITING.TITLE: how do i set up local weekly legacy in my area
WRITING.TEXT:
Heyo reddit! I want to run a local legacy thing on a weekly basis. i live in a major metropolitan city, but the western half of that city dosent have any stores, nevermind legacy. the other places that have weeklys are at the far east end or the center north. i'm far west.
the problem is I've never really done this before and legacy players are harder to herd than a bunch of cats.
questions:
1: where do i do this? i have seating and tables for 8 people comfortably at my apartment, but it's my apartment so... alternatively is the local mall, but im pretty sure its not open late enough. Help?
2: prize support is the easiest part, ironically. %100 into prize pool, done and done. totally willing to eat a loss here in order to provide like coffee or snacks to the players or whatever.
3: lending decks and cards. Im close to finishing my second legacy deck and am a bunch of recently spiked modern cards away from two more. totally willing to lend shit, but dont know the etiquite for that. help?
4: rules enforcement: it may be a very slight exaggeration to say there are as many judges as non- judge legacy players locally, but only a very slight exaggeration. the problems come with stuff like: 4a: can i play the event and run the event? 4b: can a judge play the event and judge the event if its non-sanctioned like this? 4c: local players wont play in this unless there is prize support. this makes the previous two things maybe a little more dicey than they might be otherwise.
5: how do i advertise this? facebook didnt work so hot last time i sorta tried this, but obviously ill try again. what other avenues should i explore?
edit: should i just give the city to stop people assuming i live in a small town despite saying major metropolitan area? how about biggest city in the province?
ug enchantress is much closer to unplayable since the land drop rule change gimped words of wind.

the problem is more that chalice is pretty disruptive to the base plan against eldrazi. if they chalice, elephant grass isn't an option. youv'e just got moat/sphere/quick confinement lock,all of which now have to happen with no guile to search nor accelerants for mana advantage. sanctum is much worse now too.

Theres basically Two directions you can go in.
the first is with the rest in peace helm win condition. these decks tend to be stronger against discard and stoneblade strategies, as well as control strategies that utilize the graveyard. decay is a boning, and somtimes BGx also has golgari charm.
the second is with replenish as a focal point. these decks have more resillience to countermagic and decay in exchange for having a more awkward win condition.
no enchantress list can reliably beat any form of combo deck without introducing large amounts of dissynergy. TES, ANT, sneak show, painter stone, omni-tell, elves, belcher, oops all spells, reanimator of the UB or BR variety.
all of these decks either go under you, interact with your first hate card then kill you, or sidestep your hate/locks almost entirely in the case of elves. you have no turn 0 or 1 interaction.
i haven't played this vs eldrazi yet, but i cant imagine chalice plus clock is good news either.
lastly, the reason the lists are varied is because a lot of normally sacred cows get slaughtered depending on what you are expecting to see, and then certain card choices - most of them actually - inform others in the deck. for example, miracles can't function properly with suppression field in play. combined with choke, this is close to a hard lock, and pretty easy to set up with replenish, but all of this is a total nonbo with rip-helm...
if you do decide to consider playing this thing, know that miracles is by far your best matchup. their cards do not line up well at all against yours.
know also that a splash of some sort will always be more beneficial than straight GW. red offers words of war and blood moon as well as sick seal of fire tech against delver in replenish strategies. blue gives you energy field in rest in peace builds. in the eye of chaos is pretty hit or miss nowadays though, but it was a house against dig through time. black offers doomwake giant in replenish builds(dont laugh) and discard out of the board.
good luck! don't emrakul annihilate anyone i wouldn't!

WRITING.TEXT: Why isnt this card played more? it seems like it is very hard to lose the red aggro mirror with this card in play, or even in general against red aggro decks. does burn just not make up enough of the meta?
If you want one spell in the yard yeah. If you're actually going to need all four, gifts is what you want.

I'm pretty sure this takes half as many slots. you then fill the rest with way more disruption than doomsday has. Also, doomsday makes you lose half your life and is way more all in. You dont have the option to bolt your opponent out or something if you screw up. 12 Slots.

I have read the card intuition. It does not get four spells. This is very important. Three copies of the same spell is not important. The first, when conditions are met, wins the game. The second still does, but the conditions are more resource intensive, either in deckbuilding or in gameplay or both.

intuition does not do what this card does in specifically this instance. if the plan was at any point to gifts for value, yes, intuition would be the card i want. but the fact that gifts gets four cards is important here, because you actually do need them all in your hand or graveyard.

d rit - cabal rit -pif - d rit - cabal rit - seething song hold priority increasing vengence the song - ( 4 black 15 red in pool)- manamorphose red to blue, recast gifts, get past in flames tendrils, two extras, recast PIF and tendrils ftw. There's some variation, rarely you need a little more, sometimes you need a little less, but the absolute most you will ever need assuming no opposition is 6 IMS and two of the six key bits. i think there are 15 different combinations of these, and i think only 5 of those need 6 IMS. I'm not 100% sure, uncharted waters here!

i figured the reason to play this over storm is that you then have 12 slots on the combo instead of 38 or whatever ANT has. consider a disruption suite of : counter top, force of will, thoughtseize with strix and bolt to buy time and brainstorm to tie it together. the closest comparison would be sneak and show or other "slow combo" and i could be mistaken, but i think this takes up less slots than all of those.

the cards devoted to the combo are * 2 pif * 2 dark ritual * 2 cabal ritual *1 increasing vengence *1 seething song *1 manamophphose *1 tendrils with the rest just being a grixis control list probably. The pile is hold any two of *PIF *Increasing vengence *dark ritual *cabal ritual *seething song *manamorphose and cast gifts then untap and win. Important to note that with certain initial resources, having 2 of these may not be strictly necessary.

Why does the answer depend on the pile? I want to know because it may be better to just fork over a list. Assume that 3 cards are mostly dead outside the combo, and further assume the deck can combo without casting gifts if nesccesary.

WRITING.TEXT:
going to a legacy monthly 1k today, and need some advice putting together a death and taxes sideboard. my meta has a higher than usual concentration of Lands and pox, and most of the miracles players also own grixis delver so they can go either way. the sideboard looks like this right now:

the tendrils in main is bad because A: you have no way to really find it and B: The tendrils plan is plan D anyways. You're really supposed to only use it to make a grislebrand hit immediately lethal, in the case that you weren't able to find and reanimate sufficient redundant fat. It's a corner case that comes up often enough to be worth a slot in the sideboard. Yeah, Lowry's list needed some tuning. I also got the impression from the article he didn't want to screw around with it too much, or at least that he didn't feel comfortable doing so.
[sure](http://deckstats.net/deck-8622526-e22b497f4a8d1ea2da34247cf527aa58.html)

I'm not so sure a deck with this much redundancy has as much inherent consistency problems as a typical non-blue combo deck. However, I also believe that this is less consistent than your typical reanimator shell. I consider this to be the TES to Reanimators ANT- not the optimal choice all the time, but a solid option if you want to reanimate but there are too many deathrites in the room.
force is beat by protection hands and this deck, like storm, has mana such that daze can be played around sometimes. this said, you're correct in that sometimes you just have to go for it and lose to force. Its not like we're the only combo deck that's like that either.
lastly, you wouldn't believe the number of terrible or outdated list's of this I've seen. I'm not saying mine is perfect(there are some slightly budget manabase options, for instance) but having the right distribution is key for this list. Maybe we can compare lists.
